titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Individual manuscripts, publications, and artifacts, 150 AD. - 1998 MS2135
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Individual manuscripts, publications, and artifacts
did.abstract: This artificial collection was created to manage documents that are too small to be separate collections of their own. Includes individual manuscripts, undated; Elbridge Colby's "The National Guard of the United States", 1903-1945; Book Arts Specimens, 1600 ca- 1850 ca.; Performing Arts Material, 1890-1980; Gay and lesbian publications, 1994-1998; Washingtoniana magazines, journals, and newsletters, 1879-1974; Washington associations, clubs, lodges, and societies, 1845-1948.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Individual manuscripts, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The items in the collection came to the library over time through both purchases and donations.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: This artificial collection was created to manage documents that are too small to be separate collections of their own.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: Individual manuscripts, typescripts, and images, Elbridge Colby's "The National Guard of the United States," Book arts specimens, Performing arts materials, Gay and lesbian publications and ephemera, Washingtoniana magazines, journals, and newsletters, Washington associations, clubs, lodges, and societies, Middle East maps, photographs, newspapers, and Collection of European periodicals dealing with the Armenia.

did.unittitle: Individual manuscripts, typescripts, artifacts, and images

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains manuscripts, correspondence, a bond, reports, papers. Most of these items relate to some aspect of the history of Washington, D.C.

c.separatedmaterial:
Separated MaterialsThe item Document in Greek on papyrus was removed from this artificial collection and added to the Special Collections catalog. It is discoverable using the GW online catalog and housed in the Special Collections book collection (vault CG45). The call no. is PA3300.A6 S53 catalog records is for the title Document on Greek papyrus .
In 2020 Todd M. Hickey and James G. Keenan published a treatment of this document titled An Enslaved Woman Resold . Published in Papyrologica Lugduno-Batava Volume XXXVII.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: For the most part because these materials were at one point individually cataloged when moved to this manuscript collections the folders in series 1 are numbered straight through all the boxes. In addition there is no folder 88.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This is an artificial series in an artificial collection created by staff and it continues to be added to periodically. This new content is added to the end of the list of content.

did.unittitle: Shakespeare Club of Washington D.C., records Vol. 1

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This item contains the club constitution, minute books, and membership rolls. The material dates from April 13, 1872 to May 1, 1875. The club's constitution was adopted on December 28 1869. The club formed for meetings generally weekly for the reading of plays by Shakespeare and modern popular playwrights. Both men and women were members. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 73

did.unittitle: Shakespeare Club of Washington D.C., records Vol. 2

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This item contains the club constitution, minute books, and membership rolls. The material dates from April 13, 1872 to May 1, 1875. The club's constitution was adopted on December 28 1869. The club formed for meetings generally weekly for the reading of plays by Shakespeare and modern popular playwrights. Both men and women were members. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 73
See also 0029#00157

did.unittitle: Kinesiology notebook

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Notebook for Physical Education 50, a course with Helen B. Lawrence, Feb.-May, 1965, at George Washington University. The paper is by Jane Boydstun. This is an example of a GW student paper. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 6

did.unittitle: Historical photography as a tool in historic preservation: a community application

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Paper submitted in partial fulfillment of the historical photography tool requirement for the American studies Department, George Washington University. November 20, 1981. The author is Sandra Lee Kurtinitis. Sandra Kurtinitis donated this paper in 1981. This document is a sample of GW student paper. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 70

did.unittitle: Adams-Morgan: democratic action fails to save a neighborhood

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Prepared for George Washington University class, Administration in Metropolitan-Area Governments II. Includes bibliographical references (leaves 78-81). The author is Hope Marindin. This paper is an example if a GW student paper. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 108

did.unittitle: The housing problem in the District of Columbia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Paper prepared for Sociology 28-B (at George Washington University?). The author if the paper is Howard E. Stingle. This paper is an example of a GW student paper. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 76

did.unittitle: The work of the Alley Dwelling Authority in Washington, D.C.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Paper prepared for Sociology 28-B (at George Washington University?). Author is Eldon W. Wingerd. This paper is an example of a GW student paper. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 75

did.unittitle: History of the Quartermaster Corps Project: located at the George Washington University

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Under contracts W 44-109-qm-329 and W 44-109-qm-675 with the U.S. Army Quartermaster Corps, Research and Development Branch, Military Planning Division, the project's purpose was to make a survey of sources of interest to the Branch and to procure the documents or make abstracts of them. Reports were received from the War and Navy Departments, National Research Council, and several British and Canadian government offices. The author is Susan Elizabeth Boyer. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 7

did.unittitle: The Philosophies of Shakespeare and the three romances

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This notebook created by Franklin J. Jackson was apparently a project for a class at The George Washington University. Formerly IMB #8

did.unittitle: Physics lectures, notes [Vol. 1]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This volume is an example of lectures and notes and was the property of William L. Cheney. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 86

did.unittitle: Physics lectures, notes [Vol. 2]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This volume is an example of lectures and notes and was the property of William L. Cheney. A note on the title page says "Physics 500. Rice Institute 1916-1917." Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 86

did.unittitle: The counseling interview

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Lecture given in a course at GW. Taught by Mitchell Dreese, professor of Psychology and Dean of Summer Sessions. From title page: "Lecture given to the Air Force Manpower Management Course by Dr. Mitchell Dreese of The George Washington University." Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 78

did.unittitle: Chemistry II Laboratory book: Russell Barker Munroe

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Russell Barker Munroe was GW student and the son of Charles E. Munroe a Chemistry Professor at George Washington University, 1892-1918. This notebook contains notes on results of experiments. This is an example of student notes taken while a student attending a GW course. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 87

did.unittitle: A trip from Mystic, Connecticut to Northern Vermont

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Title page reads "A TRIP TO MYSTIC, CONNECTICUT, TO NORTHERN VERMONT, August 22-25, 1921. An Automobile ride from St. Albans to Montgomery Centre, along the Missisquoi River, the Birthplace and boyhood home of Dr. Samuel Harrison Greene." This document contains handwritten passages, one letter, postcards, and photographs. This volume came from ACC#571

did.unittitle: Supremacy: a play in three acts

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The address of the author Thomas C. Kemp is listed on the title page as 81 Olton Boulevard East, Acocks Green, Birmingham. There is also a note attached to the original catalog record that this work was published in London by George Allen & Unwin, 1932, c.1931. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 90

did.unittitle: Washington Barracks, medical record book

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This volume contains manuscript monthly reports on the status of water supply, sanitation, food supply, plumbing, ventilation, and clothing and health of soldiers at Washington Barracks. Also reports births and deaths at the Barracks. Established 1797, first known as Washington Arsenal; later Washington Barracks; in the 1930s named Fort Humphreys; in 1939 assumed the name of the Army War College which it served; in 1948 renamed Fort Lesley J. McNair. From the card catalog card, it is possible that this ledger may have been purchased by the department in 1995. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 104 f

did.unittitle: Medical Society of the District of Columbia. Library

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Medical Society of the District of Columbia, founded 1817. This bound volume may be dated in the 1880s. Summary: Entries for 829 titles dating from the seventeenth century through 1884, with most dating from 1850-1884. Formerly Ind Ms. Bd. 91 f

did.unittitle: Letter, George J. Abbot to Abiel Abbot

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Abbot writes to his Unitarian minister uncle in Petersborough N.H., describing the state of Unitarianism and other churches in Washington, and the state of education in the city. He mentions William Cranch, Chief Justice of the Circuit Court of the District of Columbia, as a Unitarian, and speaks approvingly of the series of lectures given by Charles Follen. The letter is signed. This letter was purchased by Gelman library in 1983. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, John Adams to Enoch Reynolds

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This letter requests payment of interest, due in June, on a loan to Columbian College, later to be George Washington University, from John Quincy Adams, the writer's father. Enoch Reynolds esq. was the Treasurer of the Columbian College. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, John Quincy Adams to George Wood

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Content of letter: to the Treasurer of the Columbian College, asking the payment of interest in the amount of $684.64 on the debt owed to him by Columbian College, which later became George Washington University. With cover, and receipt, 1842 March 5, Washington, signed by J.Q. Adams, for the sum of $8,796.23 received from the treasurer of Columbian College, later George Washington University. The letter is used by Elmer Kayser in his book Bricks without straw, p. 88. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Typed letter, signed, 1940 April 19, from Henry Morgenthau, Jr., concerning U.S. savings bonds; two typed letters signed from Gilbert Highet, concerning Highet's authorship of several books. Gift of Donald Armstrong. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Receipt

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Charles Wakefield Cadman was an American composer. This item is a signed typewritten receipt for $50 for the fund of copying Cadman's opera, Daoma, in ink. "Denver, Colorado, April 23, 1912 Received of Francis La Flesche the sum of 450 (fifty dollars) and applied to the fund of copying the opera DAOMA in ink." The source of this item is unknown. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Charles Carroll to Daniel Carroll

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This letter requests from Daniel Carroll of Duddington, President of the Bank of Washington, some certificates, the interest to be paid in London and expresses doubts that the bridge over the Potomac River can be rebuilt for the sum the directors estimate, and that the bridge will soon be financially solvent. Gelman library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letters, W.W. Corcoran

odd.head: General note
odd.p: W.W. Corcoran was an American banker and philanthropist; founder of Riggs Bank and the Corcoran Gallery of Art. The three letters, 1841 and 1883, concern financial transactions. The letter dated 1869 April 15, mentions enclosure of the catalog of his gallery. The letter dated 1877 Dec. 4, Washington, to James Grant Wilson, and letter, 1883 Feb. 20, Washington, to Gabriel Harrison, ask for information on forthcoming publications from these authors. Purchased by Gelman library in 1986. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Richard Crockett to his brother and sister

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Sergeant Richard Crockett, of the 19th Maine Regiment of the Union Army, did not take part in the 2nd Battle of Bull Run, and asks for any news of other Maine regiments in this battle. He mentions marching between forts in the District of Columbia, such as Fort Davis, Fort Dupont, and Fort Baker, and across the Potomac into Virginia, and includes a map of these areas and the Potomac River. He expresses a desire to fight the rebel forces and to hear news from home. Gelman Library purchsed this letter in 1983. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, George Washington Parke Custis to D. Rose

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This letter acknowledges receipt of, and complies with, request for George Washington Parke Custis's autograph. The letter is dated Nov. 6. The year is not provided. The original catalog card indicates the letter falls somewhere between 1820 and 1857. Logan Cowgill donated this letter in 1972. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, George Washington Parke Custis to Directors of the Washington Bridge Company

odd.head: General note
odd.p: In 1831 Long Bridge, connecting Virginia and Washington, D.C., was seriously damaged by high water and ice; it was reconstructed in 1835. Custis offers his suggestions and sketches to the Washington Bridge Company for a temporary rebuilding of the bridge, which involves the use of some hulks of schooners as supports for a narrow crossing. The letter is dated November 13. The original catalog card indicates the letter falls between 1831 and 1835 The letter also has scribbling of Ann Timms at bottom of p.2. Gelman Library purchase this letter in 1982. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: ACED-I special events survey

odd.head: General note
odd.p: First survey by the Association of Conference and Event Directors International on median salaries of university event directors. Original in: headquarters of the Association at Colorado State University. Donated to Gelman Library by ACED-I in 1994. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Autograph

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The cartoonist's autograph with a small drawing of the head of a bear saying "Think of me being in this book!" on an album page. Gelman library purchased this item in 1984. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Autograph

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The cartoonist's pen and ink autograph at the Washington star with a small drawing of the head of a teddy bear. Berryman is the originator of a cartoon showing President Theodore Roosevelt refusing to shoot a bear cub. Gelman library purchased this item in 1987. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Bedford Brown to John M. McCalla

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Former U.S. Senator Brown says he is enclosing a letter to Senator Augustus C. Dodge , which McCalla may use to obtain the position of Second Auditor of the Treasury Department, in the Pierce Administration. This letter was found in a GW library book in 1938. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Bedford Brown to John M. McCalla

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Former U.S. Senator Brown asks to borrow a pamphlet of speeches defending James Buchanan and asks for McCalla's suppport for Buchanan in the 1856 Presidential election. Found in a GW library book in 1938. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Glenn Brown to U.S. Grant, 3rd

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Glenn Brown was a washington architect and writer. The letter is a thanks Grant for liking his book, 1860-1930, memories. This letter was found in Glenn Brown's 1860-1930, memories. Washington : W.F. Roberts, 1931. (NA9127.W2B85). Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, James Buchanan to Asbury Dickens

odd.head: General note
odd.p: As Secretary of State, Buchanan requests from the Secretary of the Senate a statement for the Biennial Register of the names of the members of the Senate and officers, and the names of printers employed from 1845 Sept. 30 to 1847 Oct. 1. Gelman library purchased this letter in 1986. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Typescripts

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Columnist. Typescript with annotations of six newspaper columns, each with accompanying teletype proofs, for Oct. 7, 9, 11, 14, 16, 18, 1973. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, 1861 Sept. 8, Traveller's Rest to John G. Pollock

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This Confederate lady named Agnes writes to her cousin in the Confederate Army; mentions a report from a young soldier about the battle of Manassas, and episodes of Union soldiers' mistreatment of local residents and looting of their houses. This is a Civil War personal narrative. Purchased by Gelman library in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Jefferson Davis to M.C. Meigs

odd.head: General note
odd.p: In this letter Jefferson Davis thanks Meigs for photographs of public buildings in Washington, and thanks him for his service in their construction. The folder also contains a printed portrait of Davis. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Gustavus Fellowes Davis to Revd. Dear Sir

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Gustavus Fellowes Davis was a Baptist minister in Connecticut and an auther of religious books. The letter mentions death of Robert B. Semple; says Baptist church work going well; sends some of his publications. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letters, Melvil Dewey to personal frends [sic]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Eightieth birthday letter, using simplified spelling, summing up Dewey's life's accomplishments in establishing the American Library Association, the Lake Placid Club, and working for decimal classification and spelling reform. Accompanied by a letter from Robert Hood, 1932 Jan. 22, telling of Dewey's death on December 26, 1931. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Lydia Sanford Vail Doughty to Princess Cantacuzene

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This letter is a notarized typed letter from Mrs. Doughty, with which she enclosed some souvenirs of General Ulysses S. Grant to the princess, a granddaughter of Grant. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Aldie Mill

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Typescript concerns the history of the Aldie Mill, Aldie, Loudoun County, Va., and its first owner, Charles Fenton Mercer, first president of the C & O Canal Company, Congressman, and worker for the American Colonization Society. Also mentioned is John Singleton Mosby. Author's name is pencilled on first leaf. The original card catalog provides dating between 1950 and 1970. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, John Foster Dulles to Dean William R. Vance

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Typed letter signed to the George Washington University Department of Law, requesting that he be allowed to take moot court work during the 1910-1911 school year. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, James B. Dutton to F. H. Lathin

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The letter mentions Lathin's correspondence with his son, Fred L. Dutton, and sends a box of specimens of white marble from a capstone (of some public building). The letter also mentions that someone from the White House has just come for two small pieces of the same marble. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Ralph Emerson to Rev & Dear Brother

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Ralph Emerson was a clergyman and educator, taught ecclesiastical history at Andover Theological Seminary. The letter, possibly to Joseph Emerson, concerns the workshop at Andover Theological Seminary, in which students make boxes for sale; his children; the doctrine of free communion. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Peter Force to Th[omas] Dougherty

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Peter Force was an historian, public printer. In the letter Peter Force writes to the clerk of the House of Representatives detailing the terms of the printing of the 250 copies of: Code of laws for the District of Columbia. Washington : Davis & Force, 1819. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1986. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Sarah M. Goodrich to Andrew T. Goodrich

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Sarah M. Goodrich writes to her brother about her gratitude that his illness is over and that a soaking rain has finally occurred; mentions the arrival of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Edwards, just from Washington. Mrs. Edwards reports a lack of law and order and Sabbath observance in the capital. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Memorandum Vasilii losifovich Gurko to Mikhail Vladimirovich

odd.head: General note
odd.p: A confidential memo to the Chief of the General Staff, General Gurko, to M.V. Rodzianko, Chairman of the Gosudarstvennaia Duma, informing him of the meeting of the 28 members of the Gosudarstvennyi Sovet (Council of the Empire, a consultative body for matters of legislation) and of Gosudarstvennaia Duma (elective legislative assembly). A sober analysis of the situation and needs of the Russian Army and the home front, with suggestions for reorganization of the army, in order to continue the war in the decisive year of 1917. The document is in Russian. This document was found in George Washington University archives. Apparently it was used in a course on Russian history or economics. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Henry Wager Halleck to Major General Samuel P. Heintzelman

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Major General Halleck orders troop movements in the defense of Washington. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Joseph Henry to Joseph Cogswell

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Joseph Henry was a scientific researcher on electricity; first secretary and director of the Smithsonian Institution. Letter to Cogswell, superintendent of the Astor Library in New York, requesting the loan of Matthew Young's book, Inquiry into the Principles of Sound, in order to pursue research on sound. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1984. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Deed

odd.head: General note
odd.p: James Hoban, of Washington, D.C. (possibly the son of the architect of the White House), sells his slave, William Gettys, to William Gunton for $325.00. The slave has been held as security for a note with the Bank of Washington. Thomas Munroe, for the Bank, relinquishes ownership of the slave to Gunton. The original card catalog card indicates the deed falls between April 25 and July 01, 1833. Gelman Library purchased this deed in 1984. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Eliza Holbrook to Susan Grout

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This traveler, Eliza Holbrook, describes for her mother the route taken from Danville, Va., using private carriage, stage coach, and steamboat, to Washington, D.C., and the planned trip home to Westborough. She writes enthusiastically of the beauties of Washington. The address page is postmarked July 3, City of Washington. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1983. Formerly Ind. Ms.
Eliza Holbrook (1807-1839) was the daughter of Esquire Seth Grout and Susannah Haskell Grout (m. 1794 in Westborough, Worcester County, MA). Source: Vital Records of Westborough, Massachusetts.

did.unittitle: Letter, Amos D. Hollistan to Sylvanus

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This Presbyterian minister describes the moral and religious climate of Washington, D.C. as generally good, and is pleased with his religious work with poor blacks in the city. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1988. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Samuel Huntington to the President of Delaware [Caesar Rodney]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Samuel Huntington, as President of the Continental Congress, writes to the President of Delaware (Caesar Rodney), transmitting a copy of an Act of Congress concerning provisions for the Continental Army. He asks that the states provide supplies for the needy army. James M. Brown, Professor of Law, and Margaret C. Brown gift, in honor of William Rankin Duryee, Emeritus Professor of Research Pathology, George Washington University School of Medicine (a descendant of Huntington) 1984. Formerly, Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Roscoe Drummond, papers

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This collection contains items from the May 12, 1956 Gridiron Club Dinner. There are two draft copies of the speech "1956 Gridiron dinner speech in the dark." Also included is a program schedule, Mr. Drummond's name placard and dinner menu. Also included is Roscoe Drummond's personal Gridiron show book as president for the May 12, 1956 dinner. There are two letters one from the Secretary-General of the United Nations, dated November 27, 1964 and the other a letter in which, Edward Moore Kennedy accepts an invitation to the Gridiron Club reception, Apr. 26, 1964. Formerly Ind. Ms and HS 2725.W3 G83 1956.

did.unittitle: Nine poems for children

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Front page is a photocopy with the title "Nine poems for children" and a handwritten note that reads "Especially for Lydia Sincerely Langston Hughes Feb. 7, 1954" Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, F.R. Larkin to Editors of the Columbian Casket [and] obituary of T. Edwin Brown

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The letter, signed "Delta", concerns the proposed trip by Charles Dickens, 1867-1868, to the United States. Larkin fears that Dickens will present an unflattering picture of the U.S. in future writings. The obiturary if for T. Edwin Brown, alumnus of George Washington University. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Robert E. Lee to Elbert Turner

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Robert E. Lee was the Commander-in-chief of Confederate forces during Civil War. This signed letter thanks Elbert Turner for election as honorary member in the Columbian College (now George Washington Univerity) Philophrenian Society. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Ronald Charles Lindsay to Cloyd Heck Marvin

odd.head: General note
odd.p: In the letter Sir Ronald Charles Lindsay presents a copy of Ramsay MacDonald's American speeches. The letter was originally tipped in: McaDonald, James Ramsay. American speeches, DA566.9.M25A25 1930. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: A little girl's experience of the war

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Apparently written by a sister of Adele and Elsie Sherman. They may be the daughters of a Henry Sherman who was a clerk for the Treasury Department during and after the Civil War. The story is the description of a young girl's stay in Washington, D.C. during the Civil War. Mentions her sisters Adele and Elsie and a newborn brother. Describes a visit to the White House, seeing Abraham Lincoln, reactions to his assassination; Confederate prisoners escaping prison through their house; soldiers' marching; sick and wounded soldiers; several military alerts; her stays in several Washington boarding schools; victory parade at the end of the war. Ink inscriptions on first leaf: A.B. Sherman, E.M. Sherman, 813 Madison Avenue, NY City. Gelman Library purchased this item in 1994. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 104.

did.unittitle: Letter, Belva A. Lockwood to Ulysses Clark

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Belva Lockwood advocates woman suffrage, prohibition, arbitration, money and labor reform, and government control of railroads and telegraphs. She was the presidential candidate for the Equal Rights Party. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Order signed by Walter Lowrie as Secretary of the United States Senate

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Manuscript document signed by Walter Lowrie as Secretary, ordering the referral to the Committee on the District of Columbia the nominations of Samuel Chase to by Judge of the Orphans Court, and David A. Hall and Thompson F. Mason to be Justices of the Peace. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Wilson Lumpkin to George Wood

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Wilson Lumpkin served as a U.S. Congressman from Georgia, 1815-1817 and 1827-1831; U.S. Senator, 1837-1841; Governor of Georgia, 1831-1835. The letter describes his happy return to his family in Georgia; mentions he must soon decide if he will run again for Congress; mentions great popularity of President Andrew Jackson. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Curculio [manuscript fragment]

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Undated Latin manuscript. One page has title Curculio; the other, Comedia. In black ink with some notations in red and a decorated letter in blue. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Indenture between Ambrose Marechal and James F.M. Lucas

odd.head: General note
odd.p: DS in which Marechal, as Archbishop of Baltimore, pledges land given to the Church by Daniel Carroll of Duddington, as security to cover debts that the Rev. James F.M. Lucas has incurred on behalf of St. Peter's Church of Washington, D.C Gelman Library purchased this indenture in 1984. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Catalog of books; Schedule A

odd.head: General note
odd.p: List made in 1825 of about 1270 titles (3,034 volumes) of all the books in the Columbian College (later George Washington University) Library. This formed part of an inventory of the assets of the college made for creditors. According to E.L. Kayser's Bricks without straw (New York: Appleton-Century-Crofts, 1970), Schedule A contained also a copy of an invoice of six cases of philosophical instruments, a general statement showing the value of each of the cases, and a complete inventory of the furniture and goods of the college. The ms. described here is only the book list, as the other parts are not with it. Title transcribed from front paper wrapper. Also known as: Catalogue of the books belonging to the Library of the Columbian College in the District of Columbia -- 1825. Also known as: Columbian College Library. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Contract, Benjamin More and William Cranch

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Benjamin More was the publisher of the Washington Gazette, 1796-1798. Cranch was Chief Justice of the U.S. District Court of the District of Columbia, 1805-1855. This document is an agreement to carry on jointly a printing, bookselling, and stationer's business for five years. The expenses and profits are to be shared equally, although the business will be managed by More. Gelman Library purchased this document in 1987. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letters, Adolphe Moreau to "Cher Monsieur"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Adolphe Ferdinand Moreau (1827-1882), art critic, writes to obtain information on Alexandre Gabriel Decamps, French painter and etcher. The April letter makes an appointment to get information on the brothers of Decamps; the December letter asks in what magazine a picture by Decamps appeared. Found in Moreau's Decamps et son oeuvre. Paris : D. Jouaust, 1869 (SPEC ND553.D29M8). Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, group of Washington citizens to the Mayor of Washington, D.C.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The citizens recommend to the mayor, then Samuel N. Smallwood, that Solomon Hubbard be named market manager for the Center Market of the third ward of the city of Washington. The 32 signatures include those of Thomas Parsons and Peter Lenox. With address leaf. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1984. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letters, Iris Murdoch to Robin Waterfield

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Iris Murdoch (1919-) writes holograph notes to this antiquarian book dealer: 1978 Nov. 9, refusing a invitation; 1981 Nov. 8, refusing a request to write a preface to a book of poems; 1981 Nov. 20, describing herself as a "Buddhist Anglican"; and 1981 Dec. 4, briefly describing her religious beliefs. The letters are in chronological order. Gift, 1983, of J. William and Nina Matheson. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Stephen Olin to Thomas Sewall

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Stephen Olin was a Methodist clergyman, president of Weslyan University, 1842-1851. The letter presents condolences to the Rev. Sewall upon the death of his father, Dr. Thomas Sewall, who was on the medical college staff of Columbian College (now George Washington University). Olin praises the medical care he received from Dr. Sewall. Provenance: Letter originally attached to paste-down of vol 1 of: The works of Stephen Olin. New York : Harper, 1852. Olin book with letter gift of Isabel Sewall. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Eugene O'Neill to Courtland Baker

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The letter expresses thanks for Prof. Baker's appreciation of two plays. Letter has handwritten note that Courtland Baker was an Associate Professor of Eng.[English] at The George Washington University. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Seth Pease to "Dear Sir"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Seth Pease was a government surveyor and astronomer. Here he describes the capture of Washington by the British, Aug. 24, 1814, including destruction of public offices, and is uncertain whether more destruction will occur. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1983. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Seth Pease to "Dear Sir"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Seth Pease was a government surveyor and astronomer. Following the capture of Washington by the British, Aug. 24, 1814, he predicts the removal of the seat of government from Washington. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1983. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Katherine Anne Porter to Dr. William L. Turner

odd.head: General note
odd.p: In this letter, Katherine Anne Porter declines an invitation to lecture to Dr. Turner's classes at The George Washington University. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, A.B. Quinby to Mrs. Gen [Alexander] Macomb

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The letter mentions Quinby's attempts to gain a position at the University of Pennsylvania; if unsuccessful at this, seeks to gain Mrs. Macomb's help in obtaining a faculty position in Washington, probably at Columbian College, now George Washington University. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Wethers Smith sent to Thomas J. Peacock

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Wethers Smith was a Civil War soldier, probably in the Union Army. Smith, in this document sent to Thomas J. Peacock, authorizes Peacock to take temporary charge of his effects if he is killed, and if pickets prevent his son, Alfred Leigh, from reaching him. Witnessed by Ann Todd. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Muriel Spark to Margaret Stanley-Wrench

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Muriel Spark (1918-), as General Secretary and Editor of the Poetry Review, refuses some poems submitted by Margaret Stanley-Wrench (1916-) J. William and Nina Matheson donated this to Gelman Library gift in 1983. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Joel Elias Spingarn to Elbridge Colby and poem by Joel Elias Spingarn

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Joel Elias Spingarn was a literary critic and reformer; taught at Columbia University in New York, 1899-1911. The letter, with a typewritten poem enclosed, is signed by Spingarn and says he may someday publish a volume of verse. These items were found in Spingarn's : The new Hesperides, and other poems. New York : Sturgis & Walton, 1911. (PS3537.P66N4 1911). Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letters, Frank Sullivan to Milton Crane and Frank Sullivan to Peter Crane

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Frank Sullivan was a humorist, writer for the New Yorker. The letter to Peter Crane concerning Peter's plans for a new magazine and his disapproval of overdevelopment of scenic areas. The letter to Milton Crane praising Peter Crane. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, E.G. Squier to J. W. Doughty

odd.head: General note
odd.p: E.G.Squier was an author and diplomat, secretary, 1853, of the Honduras Interoceanic Railway. The letter advises recipient against seeking employment with the Honduras Interoceanic Railway Company. Originally the letter had a map enclosed: Map of Nigaragua : showing its departmental divisions and projected routes of interoceanic communication / by E.G. Squier. New York : Sarony & Major, 1851. (now in SPEC maps, G4850 1851 .S78). Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Charles Sumner to unnamed recipient

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Charles Sumner was a senator. In the letter he agrees to recommend the recipient for a commission in the U.S. Army, but warns him of the large number of applicants for each commission. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Inscription

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Inscription reads: "I so wish I were a little boy about 12 or 14 years old!" On paper reading: "22. Barkston Gardens, Earls Court S.W." Found in vol. 20 of Ellen Terry extra-illustrated Shakespeare, SPEC PR2753.H461 1901 f Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Mark Twain to "Dear Sir"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Mark Twain, writing under his real name, Samuel Langhorne Clemens, refuses an invitation. The original catalog card indicates that the letter is dated between 1884-1910. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Charles Moore to Elihu Root and Arlington Memorial Bridge report

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The United States National Commission of Fine Arts was established in 1910. Typed letter signed by Charles Moore, chairman of the Commission of Fine Arts, to Elihu Root, enclosing a mechanically reproduced report concerned the location of the proposed Arlington Memorial Bridge. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Bush[rod] Washington to Walter Jones

odd.head: General note
odd.p: As executor of George Washington's estate, B. Washington quotes from the President's will, in which he left his shares in the Potomac Company toward the establishment of a university in the District of Columbia. He then suggests to the congressman the passing of a law authorizing the use of the shares for the endowment of such a university. No educational institution ever received the benefit of the stock, however (Cf. E.L. Kayser. Bricks without straw, p. 13). Gelman Library purchased this letter from a dealer in 1981. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Richard W. West to Daniel Carroll

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Richard W. West sends from his Maryland estate a note for the bank; address leaf calculations in Daniel Carroll's hand. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Charles Evans Whittaker to Roscoe Drummond

odd.head: General note
odd.p: In the letter, Charles Evans Whittaker, retired Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States declines an invitation to the Gridiron Club dinner, Apr. 25, l964. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Memorandum to Tsar Nicholas II

odd.head: General note
odd.p: An appeal to Tsar Nicholas II, probably in early 1917, by members of the special council of the Gosudarstvennyi? Sovet and the Duma, asking him to take under consideration the serious shortcomings in the Russian army as well as on the home front, with suggestions about what should be done to save the situation in order to continue the war. Found in George Washington University archives. Apparently used in a course on Russian history or economics. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Bill of sale

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Benjamin Ogle Tayloe was the son of John Tayloe, builder of the Octagon House in Washington, D.C. Summary: Holograph document by which Tayloe, as executor of his father's estate,sells slaves, Emily and her daughter Catharine, to Emily's husband, the freed Charles Stuard, for $150.00. Signed by clerk William Brent, father of the first mayor of Washington. Gelman Library purchased this document in 1997. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Document, appointing James S. Chambers as the Navy agent for the Port of Philadelphia

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Printed document with manuscript inserts, appointing James S. Chambers as the Navy agent for the Port of Philadelphia. Signed by Abraham Lincoln as President of the United States and Gideon Welles as Secretary of the Navy. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Document, by the President of the United States of America

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Ship's paper (printed form) with illustrations of a ship and of lighthouse at top of leaf, with signatures of Abraham Lincoln as President of the United States and William H. Seward as Secretary of State, but with no other manuscript inserts. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, Stephen Decatur to James L. Smith

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Stephen Decatur was an American naval hero of the War of 1812. The letter apologizes for the delay in returning a paper signed by the mayor of Washington (Benjamin G. Orr). Attributes the delay to the difficulty of finding the mayor, who is involved in several business enterprises, including brickmaking. Gelman Library purchased this letter in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Washington Canal Company, papers

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The second Washington Canal Company, chartered in 1809, built the canal between 1810 and 1815. The company failed financially and was bought out by the city of Washington in 1831. These items Include ms. plan, 1815, April 11, of part of the canal; LS, 1821 Oct. 12, from Frederick May, President of the company, to Samuel N. Smallwood, Mayor of Washington, concerning continuation of a stone wall on the line of the canal, and a basin at Market Square; LS, 1821, Oct. 17, from Smallwood, forwarding the above letter to the Washington Common Council; and a ms. document, unsigned, agreeing that the corporation of Washington and the canal company will construct a basin at Market Square. Gelman Library purchased these materials in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Indenture

odd.head: General note
odd.p: William Meriwether sells land in Hanover County, Virginia, to John Thomson, merchant. Printed form filled in by hand and signed by Meriwether and 3 witnesses. Gelman Library purchased this item in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Indenture

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Ephram I. Hoyt sells to Suttle [sic] his Georgetown blacksmith shop and stable, with its iron and coal, for $75.00. Gelman Library purchased this indenture in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Document

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Ship's paper (printed form) in French, English, and Dutch with manuscript inserts in English, for Henry Rust, Jr. for the brigantine Columbia. Signed by George Washington as President of the United States; countersigned by Joseph Hiller, Collector of Customs; witnessed by Edward Norris, notary public for the port of Salem, Mass. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Proclamation

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Formerly ACC#734 This item is a proclamation by Mayor Marion Barry dedicating august 23, 1998 as the 35th anniversary of the march on washington day, schedules.

did.unittitle: Indenture

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The indenture arranges a loan of five thousand dollars for five years, with the church building and grounds as security, because of the church's "present pecuniary embarrassment." Gelman Library purchased this document in 1983. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Document

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The document relays the appointment of William Fitch as Notary Public in the City of Washington, for five years; Signed by President Chester A. Arthur and Secretary of State F.T. Frelinghuysen. Gelman Library purchased this document in 1985. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Little Falls Mission M.E. Church under the auspices of the Dumbarton St. M.E. Chuch

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Explains how the Dumbarton Street congregation organized to build a structure near Chain Bridge to replace one where services were held on the second floor. Lists members of the mission, contributors, trustees, and building committee. Gelman Library purchased this document in 2002. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Indenture

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Indenture signed by Nicholas Overbury, father of sir Thomas Overbury (1581-1613). Accompanied by another unsigned indenture dated Sept. 26, in the 22nd year of the reign of Henry VIII. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: Letter, George Washington to Governor William Livingston

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Postscript to a ms. letter of the same date, in the handwriting of Robert Hanson Harrison and signed by Washington; describes British ships at Sandy Hook, N.J., assumed to be carrying Sir Henry Clinton; conveys urgent need for more troops. Also within the box is a transcript of the letter from the book "The Writings of George Washington from the Original Manuscript Sources 1745-1799" edited by John C. Fitzpatrick. Formerly Ind. Ms.

did.unittitle: History of 1925 F Street, N.W. Washington D.C.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This is an history of the building that houses the F Street Club, Washington, D.C. It was compiled by Mrs. Elden Billings, Columbia Historical Society. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 54.

did.unittitle: A few notes on Hillwood

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This businesswoman and philanthropist describes the rooms in her Washington home. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 52.

did.unittitle: Foggy Bottom: this is how they lived

odd.head: General note
odd.p: An architectural history of Square 43 in Foggy Bottom (Washington, D.C.), a triangular block bounded by 23rd and 24th Streets, G Street and Virginia Avenue. Written for a course at George Washington University, History of Washington, D.C. Mimi Minnick donated this document in 1986. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 51.

did.unittitle: Force genealogy

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Apparently by Edward Stead, grandson of William Quereau Force. Genealogy of the Force family, including biographies of Peter Force and William Quereau Force. Based on a paper by Cynthia Force Stead with additional information from Margaret Force Hunter. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 36.

did.unittitle: William McLain Diary

odd.head: General note
odd.p: William McLain was a Presbyterian minister, pastor of First Presbyterian Church (Washington, D.C.), 1837-1840. In this holograph volume, McLain describes his pastoral work in small towns in New Haven Co., Conn.; his trip by steamboat and stage coach to see his dying father in Champaign Co., Ohio; his trip back to New York, stopping at Miami University and Lane Theological Seminary, and briefly at Washington, D.C.; his trip by steamboat from New York to New Orleans; and his pastoral work in New Orleans with mention of the controversy surrounding the pastorate of Joel Parker. Laid in the back of the volume are a 15 page ms. sermon and a 4-page pamphlet condemning ladies' corsets. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 15.

did.unittitle: Field catalogue of transit stars

odd.head: General note
odd.p: George Davidson, a geographer and astronomer, worked for the U.S. Coast Survey, 1845-1895, and was in charge in 1850 of making an accurate survey of the Pacific coast to meet the needs of navigation. William Healey Dall (1845-1927) was a naturalist who also worked for the U.S. Coast Survey, 1871-1884. Title from cover. The ms. is apparently a transcript of Davidson's Field catalogue of 983 transit stars. Washington : Govt. Print. Off., 1874. Front free endpaper has two inscriptions: "Copied from Prof. Davidson's Ms. List July 10-17, 1871, San Francisco, Cal." and "Property of W.H. Dall". Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 4.

did.unittitle: George Washington, portrait

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Text with portrait. "Engraved by W. Humphreys. WASHINGTON. From a Picture by gilbert stewart in the posession of T. B. Barklay Esq. of Liverpool. Under the Superintendance of the Society of the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge. London Published by Charles Knight. Ludgate Street." "With the Compliments of Stephen Joel Trachtenberg President The George Washington University Washington DC" Formerly ACC#689. Received by the University Archives in April 1998.

did.unittitle: Autograph book

odd.head: General note
odd.p: J. B. McCarthy was Washington correspondent of the San Francisco chronicle, published by M.H. De Young. The volume contains autographs of Washington correspondents of American newspapers, and some U.S. Senators. Gift of Wood Gray, 1968. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 67.

did.unittitle: John Quincy Adams

odd.head: General note
odd.p: A signed photograph of John Quincy Adams (11 x 7 cm.) and a signature frank of his from a letter to John Marston. Anonymous gift in 1950. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 16.

did.unittitle: Memory book

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Emily Marston was the daughter of John Marston, patriot of the American Revolution. Memory book of this young woman contains chiefly holograph signed entries, expressing good wishes toward her, or giving advice, sometimes in a poetic or allegorical form, about conduct of life. Contains entries by members of her family, and friends, including William Staughton, Thomas B. Adams, and John Adams (signed by him only), and others. Anonymous gift, 1950. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 16.

did.unittitle: Oral history interview

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Interview with Howard Gillette, Jr. of the American Studies Program of George Washington University. Discusses his career in governmental posts and his role in Democratic party politics in the District of Columbia. Interview done by Tilford Dudley a public affairs attorney. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 62. Gift of Tilford E. Dudley, 1986?

did.unittitle: Portraits of George Washington

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Scrapbook of portraits of George Washington. Twenty portraits including engravings and portraits cut from periodicals and books. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 105 ff.

did.unittitle: Ulysses S. Grant manuscript sheet from personal memoirs

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This is a sheet from ms. of Personal memoirs of Gen. U.S. Grant in his own handwriting. Grant mentions his son Frederick Dent Grant's presence at the Battle of Port Gibson. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 65 f.

did.unittitle: Samuel Blodget property ledger

odd.head: General note
odd.p: A complete discussion of this ms. appears in: The one millionth volume of the Gelman Library / David S. Zeidberg. Washington, D.C. : The George Washington University, 1984. Samuel Blodget, a merchant and architect, invested heavily in early Washington real estate. He died intestate, leaving his estate in litigation. This ms. ledger book, in several hands, is the work of Blodget descendents and their agents in an attempt to establish correct order of transfer of his property. P. 32-34 are by William F. Boogher (last date 1885). There is a ms. document tipped in the inside front cover, and 3 ms. documents laid inside the back cover. Gift of Albert H. Small, 1984. The official One Millionth Volume of the Gelman Library. Formerly Ind. Ms. Bd. 14.

did.unittitle: I heard Lincoln that day

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This record album was donated by Professor, David Grier. Note with the record: "We are confident that you will not only enjoy but appreciate this unusual record. The original recording was made while Mr. Rathvon was speaking over short wave at the studios of WRUL. At that time the technique of reproducing the human voice under such circumstances was still in the experimental stage. Consequently imperfections unavoidably resulted and all of them could not be eliminated in this long-playing record, hence some fading and background noises in the latter part. Mr. Rathvon was a boy of nine when he heard Abraham Lincoln give this immortal address." The record says "Copied from orignal narration as recorded February 12, 1938."

did.unittitle: Cartoon

odd.head: General note
odd.p: W. A. Rogers was a political cartoonist during the late 1800s and early 1900s. Many of his cartoons appeared in Harper's Weekly. This item is a political cartoon by W.A. Rogers in the "Washington Post."
Formerly ACC#551

did.unittitle: Cartoon

odd.head: General note
odd.p: James T. Berryman (1902-1971) was the son of Clifford K. Berryman (1869-1949). James T. Berryman won the Pulitzer prize in 1950 for his cartoon, "All Set for a Super-Secret Session in Washington." This is one sheet with two political cartoons by James Berryman. They were printed in the "Washington Star." One cartoon dealt with President Johnson and is autographed. ca. 1960s

did.unittitle: Tilden Gardens grounds committee records

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Constructed in the 1920s, Tilden Gardens is the first suburban-style apartments in Cleveland Park. The complex sits on a 5-acre triangular block on Connecticut Avenue. The architects based their cross-shaped floor plan for Tilden Gardens on Philadelphia's Alden Park. Designed by Parks & Baxter and Harry L. Edwards, these units opened between 1927 and 1930. The extensive landscaping of this sloping five-acre site was done by landscape architect Henry Bauer, with fountains, pools, pergolas, and terraces. Four buildings converted to co-op in 1939.

odd.p: Harry Baum gave a lecture to the students of professor Joe Jeff Goldblatt in 1998. At the time he was 87 years old and was one of the leaders in the European meetings industry. Professor Goldblatt requested a copy of the speech be preserved in Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Martha Perske is a self-taught illustrator who produces pencil drawings of people with disabilities. Martha Perske's work has been recognized by most of the major disability organizations in the Western world. She illustrated major reports on mental retardation for Presidents Nixon and Carter, designed the International Year of Disabled Persons commemorative stamp, and drew the persons with disabilities for Marlo Thomas's "Free to Be a Family." She was commissioned to present an autographed drawing to Diana, Princess of Wales, and she drew the illustration for an attitude-change campaign jointly sponsored by Johnson & Johnson and the Arc of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a pencil drawing of seven children with various disabilites. Some of the children are drawn with animals.

did.unittitle: Four 1901 manuscript letters of qualification from African American women seeking teaching positions for cooking in the Washington, DC school

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: These four letters were addressed to Emma S. Jacobs, Director of Domestic Service in Public Schools, in Washington, DC. Sent in the fall of 1901, these letters from four different women contain lists of their credentials, including what home economics and cooking science courses and programs they may have attended, what positions they have held recently, and the salaries paid for those positions.

did.unittitle: Family photo album of Mrs. H.B. Parker, mother-in-law of the Hon. David Jayne Hill, Ambassador to Germany, Holland, and Switzerland under President William Howard Taft

odd.head: General
odd.p: This photo album is approximately 6"x 4"x 3" and is emerald green. The word "Album" is written along the spine in gold, old style font. The album contains a notecard explaining that this album is the "family photo album of Mrs. H. B. Parker, Mother-in-Law of the Hon. David Jayne Hill, Ambassador to Germany, Holland, and Switzerland under President William Howard Taft."
The album also contains two silk bookmarks. One is cream-colored and has "H.B. Parker 1851" stitched onto it. The other is blue with a cross stitched on it.

There are 46 individual portraits in the album. The subjects are men and women of all ages, including multiple portraits of infants and young children. Some have been hand-colored. Each portrait is matted on its own page. None of the photographs are labeled or dated.

These photographs are likely albumen prints because of their sepia tone and glossy finish. Albumen professional portraits such as these were called carte de visites (CDVs), a style of photograph invented in 1854 which became wildly popular around 1860. CDVs were traded amongst friends and family and acted as calling cards.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Friends of the House of Mercy/Rosement Center was organized by the Episcopal Church. The House of Mercy started in the 1800s as a place to help women who had been prostitutes. The first location was on K street and at some point relocated to the Mt. Pleasant neighborhood. In addition to helping women it also had a nursery and pre-school. This publication documents the founding of the Rosemont Center as an center for early education.

did.unittitle: Washington Light Infantry scrapbook

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Estate of Josephine R. Shepard November 05, 2020 (accession 2020.027)

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Founded in 1807, the Washington Light Infantry is a military and social organization located in Charleston, South Carolina and still active in the United States. The company was first mustered into active service during the War of 1812, but did not see combat as British troops did not invade South Carolina. In 1836, the company was activated and sent to Florida to combat hostile Seminole Indians during the Seminole Wars. They guarded the city of St. Augustine. Six years later, the company helped establish the South Carolina Military Academy (now The Citadel). During the Mexican–American War, the company became part of the Palmetto Regiment and marched into Mexico City in the army of Winfield Scott. When South Carolina seceded from the Union in early 1861, the Washington Light Artillery reformed into three distinct companies and served in the Confederate Army during the American Civil War. In 1916, the unit took the field again, serving as border guards with Mexico near El Paso, Texas, at the request of President Woodrow Wilson. A year later, following the United States' entry into World War I, the WLI served in the United States Army overseas in the 105th Ammunition Train, 55th Field Artillery Brigade, 30th Division. A military banquet is held in Charleston annually on February 22 coincident with Washington's Birthday. [information found the Wikipedia article: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Light_Infantry]

Washingtoniana magazines, journals, and newsletters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains magazines that were published in Washington, D.C. The magazines date from 1879- ca. 1974. Many of these appear to be publications of one individual or perhaps a small number of individuals. The topics include religion, washington society, banking, and literature
In all instances the folder contains only one or at most four issues of a particular journal or magazine.

The Woodlothian

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Woodlothian was a publication for the employees of the Woodward & Lothrop Department Store. The newsletter contains articles about the history of the store and its founders Samuel Walter Woodward and Alvin Mason Lothrop, official instructions for staff, staff athletic club scores and highlights, writings about employee vacations as well as information about the health of employees. The "Doings of the Store Family" section contains personal data such as notes regarding marriages, births, and vacations for each floor of the store.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: The Historical Society of Washington DC holds issues of the Woodlothian from 1924-1994.

did.unittitle: Washington associations, clubs, lodges, and societies

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains programs, handbooks, certificates of incorporation, bylaws, and membership data for civic associations, masonic lodges, and service organizations located within Washington D.C. These materials date from 1845-1948 with the bulk of the material falling between 1845-1912.
